author: maushue

title: Chicago Coin Relay Finger bracket support

description.text:
The Fibre plate that moves the switch stack on my Score Reset Relay snapped. I do not have any spares and making a replacement would take a bit of effort. Far easier to glue the broken one back together, but due to the thin parts it would need supports so it wouldn't break again.
Three minutes with a vernier and sketchup and a support bracket was made. Its a tight friction fit, that coupled with superglue and the pinball amchine was back in action in a matter of minutes.
Printed it out with 88% fill to give it strength, made with ABS

title: Clasp | Handy Pendant Light, Iphone Cord Dock, Power Switch Cover, Table Lamp in One
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Avooq team thought it would be interesting to turn the natural aesthetics of the human hand into an eye catching functional product. What we came up with is Clasp. Clasp has been designed to work with any corded appliance. It's two part shell provides a cover for anything between the power point and the device cord hiding all the unsightly areas including the power point socket of the appliance cord. How to use Clasp:

  • Print the two components. If you are using it as a power plug cover you will only need to print the hand.

  • Insert your desired appliance cord and assemble the two parts together with a twist and click.

  • Let us know what you think.

  • Enjoy.
    • Recommended Print Settings:
  • 0.15 Layer Height
  • 10% Support Angle
  • Works best with ABS filaments.
    • Team Avooq.

Magnet holder for Hall sensor based Y-endstop on I3Steel.

0.4mm layers, 0.4mm nozzle.
Dimensions are small, meaning that it will print solid, no matter what degree of infill you select. After printing, use a 6mm drill to finish the hole for the magnet (I used a 6mm diameter, 4 mm thick neodymium magnet).
Use a 2.5mm drill from one side and a 3mm drill from the other side, to prepare the small holes for a bolt.
The bolt will cut it's own thread. No need for a nut. I have press fitted the magnet, but you could superglue it if you want to (after making sure that it has the right polarity :-)

title: Shattered: A Dark Steampunk Tabletop RPG

description.text: Enter the horrifying new world that is Feneryss, all that is left of the world thousands of years after an event that is called only the Reckoning. Will you keep your humanity? Or will you mutate into something truly terrifying and beautiful? This is a adaptation of the artwork for the race known as the Wretched from the upcoming game Shattered, an amazing looking new RPG that can be found at https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/itsneverdarkenough/shattered-a-dark-steampunk-tabletop-rpg/description. The game has officially been funded! It isn't to late to get the book, just go to the Kickstarter page and click the "Pre-Order Now!" button. A keychain of the skull gas mask can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:758023 On my profile, I currently have a collection called "Shattered RPG" dedicated to the minifigures that I will print and use in the game. I will be adding to it whenever I find something worthy and appropriate. If you are interested, check it out. This game is going to be incredible.

This was created by outlining the incredible artwork for the game in Blender, point by point, vertex by vertex and adapting it from there.  
I would recommend not using the program Slic3r to generate gcode for this part, it will take seemingly an almost infinite amount of time to slice it. Cura worked far better for generating the gcode.   
If you have glow-in-the-dark filament, I would highly recommend printing this with that type of plastic. The pictures shown are printed in it, and it looks amazing in the darkness.

title: Skull Gas Mask Keychain from Shattered RPG

description.text:
This is the memorable Skull gas mask from the artwork for the upcoming RPG Shattered. I was so encaptured by the art and the RPG itself that I had to convert it to 3D printable format.The Wretched are certainly my favorite of all the races in the game.
This was made by outlining the original artwork for the game in Blender, vertex by vertex. The gas mask belongs to a member of the race of the Wretched, some terrible and mutated remnants of humanity left over from the Reckoning. These people wander the scarred world, with deformities that they may be shunned for, but can be used to achieve great power if they can control them. It is a curse, and yet almost a gift, and the Wretched must bear this gift until the end of days and perhaps longer. Shattered RPG is currently on Kickstarter and can be found here: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/itsneverdarkenough/shattered-a-dark-steampunk-tabletop-rpg/description The full adaptation of the artwork can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:758015

title: 182mm  X axis full print bed upgrade Printrbot simple 1405 makers edition 2015

description.text:
This now can utilize 182mm the complete x axis of the print bed:-)!! I downloaded the upgrade (link below) but it was for a different iteration so I designed this one. The iteration I've posted of the upgrade mentioned, Is redesigned to fit the printrbot simple that I got in December 2014. I've added an x axis zero stop screw and belt tensioners to each side of the upgrade for ease of installation and print quality.
This can be printed on a printrbot simple 1405. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:215294

You need GT2 Belt at least 7" (175mm approx) longer than the rods you intend to use. 2) 11" 8mm rods would be adequate to utilize the full printbed. Also the key to getting the full 182mm is to counter bore the printbed screws. If you don't counter bore them then you will only be able to get around 150mm because the extruder and sensor will hit the print bed screws. I used Phillips countersunk 3mm screws 15mm long. You'll need to level the bed after you tension the belt. After you've assembled the enlarged printbed, you need to change the printers settings in...
  • Your slicing program
  • Repetier-Host printer shape in printer settings
  • Your printer board. Don't worry this is easy. To do it have your printer on and connected to Repetier. In the manual control tab, in the Gcode, type M211 X(new print bed size in mm) and hit send. EXAMPLE M211 X150 for a 150mm x axis. Then type M501 and hit send. The new print values should show in the log at the bottom. if you don't see the log then press the toggle log button next to the kill print button, and the log will show at the bottom. Once your printerboard is reprogrammed disconnect from repetier and restart your printer and repetier-host. reconnect the printer and enter M501. confirm your expanded printbed size and enjoy!!

comments.text: Are there instructions for installing this?
comments.author: rednax718

comments.text: I am having issues getting the left end to print on the stock bed. Any suggestions? I have removed skirt and brim is at the lowest setting of 1.
comments.author: itlbk333

comments.text: You dont necessarily have to reduce the skirt and brim. The way I got it to fit was by manually rotating the object in repetier-host. I forget which axis but that should be self explanatory (if not keep the object flat and rotate it so it will print without support). Start at 45 degrees then center the object. then try 46 degrees, then 47 degrees etc, until it fits. I may be wrong about the degrees, it may be a lower value but i hope this helps. If you have any more questions I'm happy to help.
comments.author: itlbk333

comments.text: Would it be possible to use this to expand the printbead to 400mm (~15.5")?
comments.author: wansho1

comments.text: I am planning on getting a 1405, but want to have a solid plan of mods to do since I would like a 400mm by 250mm printbead.
comments.author: wansho1

comments.text:
It certainly would be possible but you'll have significant problems trying to print most parts that size without a heatbed. And there are a few challenges to overcome when trying to run a heated bed on the Rev D circuit board. If you are capable of building your own printer and you want to be able to print that size you should consider the Prusa I3. Right now there's a company selling Prusa I3 kits with all the bells and whistles, for less than the Printrbot. (Link below) I Just ordered one myself and am awaiting delivery.
As far as the 400mm you'll still need to expand the build plate on the Prusa.
comments.author: wansho1

comments.text: Thanks for the advice. I think I'll try to achieve it with the printbot. The company has a really good reputation and I enjoy overcoming challenges. Would I have to make any modifications to your upgrade to achieve the larger printbead area? I won't be printing large objects at first anyway, just want to have the ability to when I want to? (I will find some way to implement a large heated bed).
comments.author: Makamaka

comments.text: are the holes 8mm exact or small? if exact my 1405 keeps printing them to small for some reason.
comments.author: crowsodown

comments.text: The holes are exact its the imperfection of the print that make it difficult.  I cleaned them out with a drill bit after printing. And yesterday I added springs on the screws for bed leveling so I drilled the holes a little larger so I could use a screw with a #2 philllips head. I will post a new pic of the leveling spring shortly.
comments.author: crowsodown

comments.text: crowsodown is correct.  The holes for the rod are too small, and the walls are too thin.  When I tried to drill out the hole to make it larger, I cracked the plastic because it was too thin.
comments.author: Makamaka

comments.text: There will be many factors affecting the accuracy of your actual print dimensions. Here's an example, Using my prusa I printed a lego piece. The piece worked perfectly. Then I switched from .4mm to .2mm resolution nozzle and printed the same stl. file and the piece was too loose to snap on to OEM parts and or even printed parts. Explaining why this happens is beyond the scope of this reply. good info here; http://manual.slic3r.org/advanced/flow-math

author: marsolf

description.text: a desgin for a car

UPDATE Uploaded a newer version with indents and the pointer raised above the top. It is slightly bigger than the smooth version so it slides on the pin easier. I used superglue to keep it in place but it doesn't really need it. So much like my volume slider replacement story
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:75396 I got this old Mackie mixer for a video recording job I do once a month. It was misshing a slider (linked above) and a volume knob. This knob has the indicator line in the right spot and correctly shows the level it is at just like the stock knobs. I had to make it a little bigger on the outside because slicing walls that thin made for some crappy prints. This printed flawlessly as soon as I made the outer walls a bit bigger. You can see the knob in action in the pictures. It is the red one :P ** My original design had the little texture lines like the original knobs but I was having so much trouble printing I thought I may have been them that was causing the issue. Now that I have it printed well I will try a new file with the texture back in and see how it does.

Smooth Version Printed the smooth version well at medium quality on Makerware with .2 mm layer hight. This file will print with no raft or supports. The medium quality allows sharpie marker to bleed through to the rest of the piece. Printing at high quality stops the bleeding. It is very tight on the rod that is on the mixer. I had to tap mine a little bit to get it on all the way. Textured Version Printed well at high quality. No raft or supports needed.

author: Jasper1984

description.text: The Ikea Rationell compost bin has served me nicely as a sink-side disposal bin, but when we lost one of the clips holding it open, I thought it'd be more fun to develop a hands-free solution instead. So here is a simple step pedal that turns the Rationell hands-free. Not the most elegant solution, but printing is minimal and it works :) Check it out >> https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zTeJ5DSyyr0

You will need: 2 x M3 12mm screws (or equivalent)
1 length of fishing line (or string)
1 x small screw
some small weights
short length of twisty wire (for gardening) ASSEMBLY:
  • Attach “Lid hook” to lid of IKEA RATIONELL bin
  • Screw “Rounded L guide” to frame of bin, add bit of wire through two holes (this provides a “cap” to prevent the line from getting off track)
  • Attach “Pedal” to “Shoe” with M3 screws (my draft version had holes too small in the shoe so I used bits of gear shafts instead)
  • Connect “Lid hook” to “Pedal”. Bin should be closed and Pedal in upright position — adjust to suit preference. When pedal is depressed, the bin lid should open sufficiently.
    • If the lid does not close when you release the pedal -- because like me you put bags inside causing friction with the lid -- then tie weights (like bolts and nuts) to the lid hook to provide the push needed.

A small 12V LED lamp.
2 bright white LEDs are mounted in series with a 330 ohm resistor. It has a triangular knob on one side for fixing a binder clip with cable ties and a 5mm hole on the other side for a string, bolt, cable tie or whatever you fancy.

0.4mm nozzle, 0.4mm layers.  
The end is painted white inside with "Enamel fix" paint.  
The LEDs are mounted by filling the tube from the back with hot melt glue.

This is a very simple design i made to fit new LED spotlights in my kitchen ceiling. The old spotlights were bigger and i needed something that looked nice and made it possible to fit the smaller spotlights in the larger hole.
This is designed in OpenSCAD and the size's are defined in the module call, so they are easily adaptable to your needs. The standing ring serves three purposes:

  • it centers the adaptor in the hole
  • it prevents draft from the ceiling into the kitchen

description.text:
Two version of the same design, the v2 actually works better with all ipads, iphone 6+ and android devices.  
The v2 will have more of a tilt than the first one if used with Ipad Air, Mini or my Iphone 6plus which I like when I have it standing on my desk. The v2 also uses less materials by having thinner walls. Also made the front lip not as high so that I easily can use my fat fingers at the lower part of my phone without taking it out of the cradle.  
The v1 cradle works for all *Pads thinner than 10mm like Ipad Air or the Ipad Mini. The Ipad Air is 7mm thick and the slot is 9mm.

The Cradle is sliced and diced w. Simply3D using 1.75mm PLA and 1mm layerheight.
I start the first layer with 2mm and hotbed on (60-110 deg. Celsius during the first 3 layers), it sticks much better. The hotend at 230 °C.

description.text:
A modern themed 6x4 picture frame.  
All letters and hearts are separate parts that snap on to the frame allowing you to make each part a different colour.  
Source files also included.  
update:09/5/15  
A user has pointed out that I have forgotten to add a printer tolerance to the frame to allow the letters to fit. This means that depending on how accurate your printer is you may not be able to fit the letters in. when I have time after exams I will fix this issue but for the moment some sanding my be required to make the letters fit.  
Alternatively follow Jetgsr's comment solution until I have time to fix it.

Gcode created using simplify3d.  
Frame was printed in ABS at 0.2mm layer height with 20% infill, 2 shells, 3 bottom solid layers and 5 solid top layers.  
Letters and hearts were printed in PLA at 0.2mm layer height with 10% infill, 2 shells, 3 solid bottom layers and 5 solid top layers.

comments.text:

So because you print each piece separate if you are out by .1 of a mm on the letter and the next and so on.
then you print the frame you will find the cut out pieces dont allow the letters to fit into the frame.

title: Horizontaler Spulenadapter für Spulenhalter MKIII / horizontal spool adaptor

description.text:
Bei diesem Bauteil handelt es sich um einen Adapter um Filamentspulen mit ungewönlichen Maßen am "Spulenhalter MKIII" für RipRapPro Ormerod Drucker verwenden zu können.
(z.B. Spulen mit ungünstigen Durchmesser zu Höhe Verhältnissen)
Mit diesem Adapter lassen sich pracktisch alle Spulen verwenden die:
  • Einen Kerndurchmesser von mindestens 27mm haben
  • nicht schwerer als 2kg sind
    Schwerere Spulen würde ich der Grundkonstruktion nicht zumuten (Z-Achse des Druckers).
    • Zu diesem Adapter gibt es einen passenden Drehteller und Aufsatzkonus.
    Der Drehteller kommt bei Spulen zum Einsatz die keine glatten Außenwände haben, und ohne diese Erweiterung nicht glatt auf den Kugelagern laufen würden.
    Der Konus kann auf den Drehteller aufgesetzt werden und errmöglicht bei Bedarf eine Zentrierung der Spule.
    (Beides findet sich in extra Dateien) Die verwendeten Kugellager sind vom preiswerten Typ "608ZZ" und werden direkt mit Schrauben der Größe M8*20 am Adapter verschraubt.
    Die Aufnahmen sind so bemessen, das die Schrauben sauber und sicher direkt im Material halten. Muttern, Unterlegscheiben u.s.w. werden nicht benötigt. Zur Befestigung am Basisteil "Spulenhalter MKIII" kann ein Stück Gewindestange M8, eine Schraube M8x50+ oder etwas ähnliches verwendet werden. Natürlich lassen sich mit diesem Adapter auch z.B. zwei 0,5kg Spulen gleichzeitig montieren. Einfach über der ersten, unteren Spule noch einen weiteren Adapter plus Spule aufsetzen und dem
    Multiextruderbetrieb steht nichts mehr im Weg. Wichtig:
    Dieser Adapter wurde für keine bestimmte Spule konstruiert, je nach Außendurchmesser der Spule kann die Filamentführung etwas schwierig werden. Hier hilft nur ausprobieren und im Zweifelsfall improvisieren.
Bitte einen Blick in die .scad Datei werfen!

title: Lock rings for smooth rods on printer

description.text:
An M8 nut converted to lock an 8mm smooth rod in place. On my P3steel there is nothing but friction to stop the rods from moving longitudinally.
This "lock nut" keeps them in place. I use them on the X-axis.
They could be used on Y and Z too, but I use other solutions there. It is easy to use and quick to adjust.

• Run an 8.1mm drill* through an M8 nut to remove the threads.
    (Caution: Hold the nut with a spanner or a machine vice when drilling!)
  • Drill a 2.5mm hole through one of the faces.
  • Thread the hole with an M3 tap.
  • Insert an M3 bolt or grub screw in the hole.
    • The nut will sometimes have to have a bit of one or to of the faces filed a bit, if you want it to be flush with the surface. *If you do not have 8.1mm drills, an 8mm drill and a bit of effort with a round file will work too. .... It can of course be printed too after the .stl file.
    The small hole is set to be 3mm, and on my printer that would mean, that after running a 2.5mm drill through the hole, an M3 bolt will cut it's own threads.
    It will not be as strong as a steel nut.
    "locknut II" has a bit more plastic for the bolt to cut a thread in. I would recommend to use that design, if you insist on printing the lock nuts rather than converting M8 nuts.

author: Peter_I

description.text: kidney cross section

Affirmative! This is a full scale model of K-9 from Doctor Who.  Certain details, such as the tail and ears were made larger to provide strength when the model is scaled down for printing. I designed the model in Autodesk Inventor 2014 from scratch.  It has been printed once using a Objet Eden 260v. (model was painted by a very talented artist)
The model is a full size K-9, scale it down to whatever size you want before printing.  Be careful with the tail and especially the ears.
This is a remix of thing:284641 by Cymon. Updated for TableTop Day 2015 and two other versions which have no date.

I recommend printing this at 0.1 mm or higher. Anything lower and the letters start drooping a bit.  
It can be printed without supports at 0.1 mm, all of the lettering is slanted to it can print upwards. It can also be scaled to almost any size depending on your printer.The bottom has been indented to improve platform adhesion/flatness.  
Please let me know if anyone has any suggestions for future modifications/additions in the comments section.

NOTE TO EARLIER VIEWERS:  Please check for new file uploads.  Thanks for your patience.
In a collaboration class assignment, my team came up with The Stripper to address the problem of trying to break through the seals on a new DVD case.  You know, when you're trying to open the new DVD you just bought, it can sometimes take longer than watching the movie (a bit of an exaggeration, but you know what I mean!).
The Stripper was developed in a class assignment in collaboration between designing (me) and marketing (them).  I designed the handle from a common office staple puller made by Stanley Bostich, because I liked the feel of it in my hand.  There was a storage compartment for more blades.  The blades were common for Xacto knives, but must be trimmed down to fit as there's no room for that long shaft of the Xacto blades.  Unfortunately, the final draft lost some of these enhancement due to time constraint.
I haven't printed one yet, but I wanted something in my "Things I Designed" area.
When I figure out the license, I will change that to the appropriate choice.  Anybody know where I can get more info on the license choices?
Print the .stl file.  Get some spare Xacto blades.  Trim them to fit.  Assemble.

description.text: Your 3D you!

Bender Bending Rodriguez, the articulated model.  He has some accessories, I'd like it if people would help create more, since there are so many. I will add accessories as I watch more episodes. Please read the instructions as they contain info on printing and assembly. Enjoy and if you like, follow me on Instagram (Simonarri).

Hey, wanna kill all humans?
This model has been switched out for the metric version. You do not have to scale to print!
Smaller parts and those with not much of a footprint could use help from a brim. For me, these were: Cigar, beam, antennae. All other pieces seem to stand on their own.
Some of the objects have numbers after their names. These numbers indicate the amount of each piece you will have to print to make one complete model. If you are painting the piece, you can print multiple eyes for different expressions.
The body took the longest to figure out. I made it with small tabs at the top and bottom of the door that will need to be cut through with a blade. I made mine serrated and have included a photo to illustrate. I had different parts of the door fuse due to printer settings. If that happens for you, a little work with the serrated blade will open it up. After the door is cut all around, gently pry it open to work the hinges loose. Clean up around the armholes and tabs on the inside with a blade so the tabs are able to be pressed and moved slightly. To assemble the shoulders, press one tab(there are 2) and insert the shoulder into the socket at the same time. The ridges in front and back both need to be set completely into the ring on the shoulder. This will allow the shoulder to rotate with a little tension. Attach 4 links to one shoulder to make an arm.
The legangle2.stl pieces are the first ones to attach to the bottom of the body for legs as they are angled slightly. Attach 5 links to this to form one leg. If the links don't fit together with a little push, run a blade around the inside hole of the link to loosen it up. Links and hands can be printed with a high infill number to make them tougher. The foot has a hole in the bottom that will fit rare earth magnets if you want to glue one in. Below are edits and additions, so be sure to check them out:
4/7- Changed beam, fits between arms now
Added "Beard." This is the only piece so far that should print with support.
Added "Headnohole" as an alternate head with no cigar hole.
"Headjar" is the container for keeping heads alive. You can print a face and glue on.
Added "Tophat"
5-29- Added link181 thru link185. Each one is .001 larger than the last. If you have issues with link18 fitting to make arms or legs, try printing 2 of link181 and see if they fit together better for you before printing 18 of them. If link181 is still too tight, move on to the next size and see if it works better for your printer.
7/22- Added 2 more supports to the bottom of the door per request
If any of these instructions are unclear, please drop me a line:)

comments.text: I have printed this and i have some major issues with the arm and leg links, the tolerance is so tight i have to take the dremel tool to all of them, Any tips?
comments.author: Sallen1215

comments.text:
The tolerances are small and are a pretty tight fit. You may need to remove any flashing inside the opening of the link-where the link touched the build plate. Just run a sharp exacto around the inside lightly and try again.
Also, if your pieces are printing out slightly oversize due to squishing layers together, the pieces will not fit together very well. Maybe measure your pieces and check them to the size of the on screen model and see if your machine is tuned. Lastly, printing at .2mm layer height made my pieces too tight and I had to print at .1mm to reduce the ridges from larger print layers.

I've found similar problems with units and scales. There are 2 issues, first: Cura is assuming the object is in mm, not inches. Second, the behavior is not the same in every stl. At least the file "eyes.stl" is interpreted in the opposite way.
Simonarri, there must be something wrong with your Rhinoceros settings, and they are also different for some files. If I import each file in c4d as mm, and export as stl in inches, cura does the work with no problems, huge and tiny ones.
By the way, I've modified the head to split the eyeballs from the rest of the model so you can print in two colors.
I've cleaned the mesh, there are some problems with points and faces, so I ended working with one side, converted to perfect symmetrical and optimized the shape and the holes for the eyeballs "extraction". I can share as a remix if anyone is interested, but I prefer to ask you first if you don't find interesting to do yourself with the actual sources and share as an official part.
Finally, I love your design, I really love it, you sir!

title: VERTEX - K8400 spacer in combination with the PRINTinZ build plate

description.text: This spacer can be used when the Glass build panel and BuildTak is replaced with the PRINTinZ flexible build plate.  The Glass build plate in combination with a BuildTak sheet is about 4.2mm thick.  The PRINTinZ build plate is about 3.5 mm thick.  The original bed clips will not hold the PRINTinZ build plate in place so I have designed a spacer that should be installed underneath the aluminium build plate to reduce the bed clips space with 0.7mm.  Remove the bed clips and install the spacer and next install the bed clips again.  This should hold the PRINTinZ flexible build plate firmly in place.  You have to print it twice for left and right!

title: M8 to Nema-17 Z-Coupler

description.text: EDIT: You probably don't want to use this. It's too rigid. I'm currently using these: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22422 (I think mine's prettier but that doesn't count for much if the prints suck!) If you need a rigid coupler these are great, but for most reprap applications (including the Printrbot Plus), give mine a miss. Sorry! A simple coupler to mount M8 threaded rods to a NEMA 17 stepper. The up arrow points up! I'm [no longer] using two of these on my Printrbot Plus and so far, [have changed my mind about them being] so good. (Don't overtighten!)

comments.text: Does this work okay? It seems as though the "plate" in the middle of the central column, separating the M8 side from the NEMA side, would hinder the "squeezing" action of this piece.
comments.author: markbrannan

comments.text: The fit is so snug that it isn't a problem. The motor side needs tapping with a screwdriver to get it on there, and the threaded rod needs screwing into the connector. The plate is really thin and can be cut out, but I don't think you'll need to.
comments.author: markbrannan

comments.text: Perhaps the piece is so rigid as the walls are so thick (they look to be something like 8 mm thick, right?). Reducing the width of these to something closer to 2 or 3 mm should allow the frame to be a bit more flexible whilst still being strong enough to use.

title: havy Crystal Skull - Acrylic Laser cut, WS2812 LED Illumination

description.text:
my first carton skull: http://www.thingiverse.com/make:129252 Remix from Plastic Corrugated Skull
by whastupdoc, published Apr 2, 2015
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:752779 Weight 4400 Gramm
2qm Acrylic 3mm
54 Layer
1x LED-Player (http://www.led-genial.de/LED-Player-spielt-LED-Effekte-von-SD-Karte-ab)
9x LED-Digi-Dots Ws2812
1x LiPo-Akku 4,3V 500mAh Don't forget to visit our site http://www.led-genial.de for further information on our technology, research and creations. Meine Interpretation der klasse Vorlage von >whastupdoc<.
Glatte zwei Quadratmeter 3mm Plexiglass gehen hierbei drauf! Das Teil wiegt entsprechend und sieht im Original Hammer aus. Ein WS2812 Strip (9 Digi-Dots) ist im 12/10mm Plexiglasrohr untergebracht, der wird von einem LED-Player von DIAMEX (http://www.led-genial.de) angesteuert und kann mit Jinx! (http://www.live-leds.de/) und LedEddy (http://www.led-genial.de/mediafiles//Sonstiges/LedEddy.zip) frei programmiert werden. Zusammengehalten wird der Schädel von zwei auf 17,5cm zugeschnittenen M5 Gewindestangen. Es braucht schon einige Kraft, alles zusammenzupressen. Vorsicht beim Anziehen der Muttern, mit Gefühl, schade wenn das Plexiglass platzt. Der LED-Strip ist im Plexiglasrohr eingeschoben - 15cm, mittig ein 4-6mm Loch um das dreipolige Kabel herauszuführen. Im Hinterteil des Schädels passt dann die Elektronik nebst Akku rein. Viel Spaß beim Nachbau, das Teil ist der absolute Hingucker!

http://youtu.be/qQlhCe8AgO4
http://youtu.be/jl9-nVuJUjI

title: Layer fan mount for leonozzle v2 - Prusa i3 (40mm fan)

description.text:
Built and mixed from many other fan parts.
FOR 40 mm FAN and gregs extruder. I recommend printing with PLA 1.75 at 0.20 layer height and 33% infill. I used kisslicer but prints well with slic3r too. IMPORTANT:
You'll need to glue the two tinny parts in order to adjust and fix the angle needed for your printer. UPDATE:
Uploaded version 4 STL files, improved.

Recommended print for kisslicer: 3 perimeters per layer
0.20mm layer height (no more than 0.30!)
set infill between 20 and 50% (recommended 33%) My tests worked fine with 1.75mm PLA and 40 mm fan.
This is a fan mount for 40mm fan and gregs extruder.

description.text:
Copper pipe supported by 2 of these things makes a holder for 3 spools of filament.
Holder fits the 2 top rails with the option of securing in place with nuts and bolts, or cable ties, or not.
Larger spool needs a center hub to adapt to the size of the copper pipe.
OR, better still, use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:735213 for the spool adapter.

Copper pipe used in plumbing is cheap, and in my case removed from the house when converting to Pex pipe. The diameter is perfect for the smaller 100M spool that arrived with the kit. For the larger 1Kg spool requires an adapter hub to clear the top of the extruders.  
Two holders are required to support a length of copper pipe.  
Bolt holes are provided in case you need to secure the holder to the printer.  
The spool adapter has a small flange and are a tight fit in the larger spools I have access to. Two of these, each side of the spool, can be tied together with wire or cable ties.

title: Self centering idler bearing for Y-axis belt.

description.text:
I did not like trying to make the belt run absolutely straight on the Y-idler. Using little pieces of paper on a steel printer just seemed wrong!
This made me think of old fashioned "crowned pullies". They are "crowned", higher in the middle, and that makes the belt stay centered. For a nice description, look here:
http://woodgears.ca/bandsaw/crowned_pulleys.html I belt sanded the bearing, to make a "crowned bearing" to use as an idler.
You have to be careful, but once it us done right, it works like a charm.

Mount the bearing on a piece of threaded rod, then grind it on a belt sander to make a nice bevel, a bit more than a third of the width of the bearing. Flip the bearing over, and grind the other side at the same angle. Holding the bearing on the sander as shown in the "children's drawing" lets it rotate, and gives a nice, symmetrical grind.
(Be very careful to make the two grinds identical!) Mount it on a piece of 8mm smooth rod, not a threaded rod or a piece of printed plastic!

I created this to have better cooing for my Mendel. This will work for the First Multi-Head Mendel with the Horizontal X-Axis rods, this will not work with the newest Version with the vertically stacked X-axis smooth rods.  
Attach this in one of the hot end locations not being used. And use the leveling screw to clamp it in place. Minor trimming may be needed to clear the leveling screw.  
I've included my solid-works model so you can modify as desired. Or add the top few layers to make it closed if your printer can handle the bridging.

Printing instructions, Print once to 100%.
Print the first 2 layers a second time.
Use a little CA Glue to attach them together to close up the shape I recommend also gluing some aluminium foil to the underside to prevent drooping from heat bed/hot ends.

description.text: Update 2017-01-28: I've made a VERY much improved version available here: http://cults3d.com/en/home/two-week-pill-container-medication-dispenser and here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2068752

I wanted a compact design for my daily pills that would also work while travelling. It only measures about 8cm in diameter but manages to contain 14+1 slots with plenty of space for all pills. Since 1 slot is always open and the current weekday is shown, it's easy to see if you remembered to take your pills or not. Slot 15 (marked with a heart) can be used for pills only needed occasionally. The lid is fastened with a simple M4 screw and nut, but you can drill it up a bit if you want a bigger screw. How hard the lid should be fastened can be adjusted with the screw. You might for example want to tighten the screw a bit if you are planning on travelling with it.
If keeping the container in a bag, insert the screw from the top and place the nut from below. If the container will remain still (like on a bed table), it will be much easier to insert the screw from below and using a wingnut to tighten it on top. Using just the pressure from your finger you can then remove the nut and lid for easy refill action.
Refilling can of course still be accomplished by simply turning the lid one day at a time. Both me and my wife have been using these containers daily for a couple of months now, and it has been working very well for both of us. Update 2015-07-08: V5 has a lid that is much easier to turn. It also has room for a washers in both the lid and bottom, which will prevent the lid from getting tighter as you turn it. The slots are slightly redesigned to avoid getting pills stuck near the center.

title: Direct Drive for BI2.5 with EZstruder with fan shroud 30x30mm

description.text:
Note: Please do not use this design, use the latest Low profile mount
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:887941 This is a direct drive mount for BI 2.5. It's simple for a single extruder. I designed a fan shroud to used with a 30x30mm fan. It can easily by used with a two hot ends (once at a time) but you will need to turn the support.

You need to remove the bowden push-fitting and fit the bowden tube directly in the metal cylinder. Print all parts than assemble them:
  • Extend the motor wiring to reach the new position of the motor.
  • Install the EzStruder on the motor.
  • Install the support on the EzStruder.
  • Cut the Bowden tube to 15mm over the aluminium plate.
  • Install the support on the retainer plate with the Center Hole retainer, a #10-24 x 50mm screw, a washer and a nut. The nut goes into the hex hole in the support and the screw with washer in the hole retainer.
  • Install the fan shroud and the supports on the motor support (use small screw, #4 metal screw).
  • The motor wiring goes into the square hole beside the fan hole.

I printed it without supports but could benefit from using supports on the holes where the axle goes.

You can store up to 5 weeks of antidepressants in this cheery little pill organizer!  The sliding lids, labeled with the days of the week, have view ports for seeing if pills have been taken, and also have friction locks to hold them shut.  You start taking your pills from the bottom so you can slide open each lid to dump out just one pill at a time.  
There is a slim-line version for small pills and a deep-dish version for horse pills.

All parts were printed in PLA, 0.2mm layer thickness, 3 perimeters and 20% infill.  Print one main pill compartment (pillbox.stl for slim-line, pillbox_deep.stl for deep-dish), 2 "S" lids (Sat., Sun.), 2 "T" lids (Tues., Thurs.) and one each of the "M", "W" and "F" lids.  
The lids may be a little tight at first, but work them back & forth and they will loosen up. All parts can probably be scaled by up to 25% or so  for larger pills.  
The visibility of the letters on the lids will vary with your filament color.  I worked a little paint into the engraved letters on this one to increase the contrast.

comments.text: I printed this and I love it except i had to reprint it because it was really small. If you are going to print this i would recommend using the bigger file then enlarging it by about 25% to be able to hold bigger sized pills.

description.text:
This thingy made of brass nozzle, stainless barrel (also called thermal barrier), aluminum heater block, aluminum heatsink and aluminum mount plate. Heating element is 6mm x 23mm 40 Watt heater cartridge. Thermistor is pre-glued with GB Weld inside brass hex M-F M3 stud, thermistor is equipped with JST connector. Thingy can be assembled or taken apart in one minute without glue or kapton tape. Everything is screw on-off. Based on Makerbot Stepstruder Mk7 hotend. Nozzle has Makerbot's modern Mk8 geometry, 0.4mm orifice diameter, but slightly larger than Mk8 outer hex size (7.9mm instead of 6.5mm because it was machined in USA from inch size stock). SS thermal barrier also similar to one used in Stepstruder. Part of the credit goes to Makerbot, which is why I call it "MB". Finally, as of Dec 2014, this hotend with improvements (PTFE lined barrel and fan with shroud) is available for purchase here
http://www.ebay.com/itm/221613331858
http://www.ebay.com/itm/221650302463
This is release candidate. Details on the construction will be published when it is released. Please check out STL for 3D View and supplied PDF drawing for dimensions.

Very fast and maneuverable, the IPV-1 patrol craft patrols Imperial sectors when Imperial Star Destroyers cannot be everywhere. They are regarded as the first line of defense against smugglers and various organizations attempting insurrection against an Imperial system, and rely on their speed to catch and disable or destroy enemy craft. Lacking hyperdrive, the IPV-1 flies specific routes along known smuggling lanes. Their objective is to maintain the peace and order of the Empire in systems the Empire controls.
Printed at 100 micron layer resolution with raft and supports. Some cleaning required.

title: DailyEarring#73: Tiny sliding train ring 4cm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
-DailyEarrings & Prologue: thingiverse.com/thing:7120 and blog at www.wap.cc  
This is still under constructions, expect the color photos, aditional carts and major tweaking in the future.  
The wheels do not turn, it's just a slide rail- but works fine!   
We decided to make it without loop and hook the rail to a big closure ring.  
//UPDATE 1: Added a color version with a tunnel and pine, which also has a modified rail. Not tested! No STL yet.  
//UPDATE 2: Added a new SKP file. The new rail prints with texture, at least the main rails; I added 0.1mm height to the wood bars, should print now (hopefully).  
The tree/tunnel version did print, but the tree was disattached. Should work now- but its very big with those extras. I might do a 3cm rail version with smaller train, but not today.  
Printing the rail upside-down makes it much smoother and the train runs nicely, so this is the best orientation.  
The train itself prints best facing up, as the glider clamp is more rigid due to the layer orientation then.  
I made them 0,1mm shorter as on the original now, else they are hard to get on (and it still should be tight enough).  
Added some images as well.

//You should consider exporting the train6.skp objects, but not all modifications are tested yet. (See update 2)  
I printed the train in all orientations (pp3dp up printer), standing and upside-down proved to be easiest to clean.  
The first rails had some inverted areas and printed all over the place, so I printed a simple version without texture. New version untested!  
Maybee thinner radius will still work, smaller slide or train will probably not look as nice anymore.  
Clean under the rail and in the sliding clip to ensure smooth motion.  
Be careful when trying to clip it onto the rail, I broke two trains (but made the clip a bit thicker on the last print, seems better now).  
Orientation of the rail: If printed on the flat side, it may be easier to clean, but I was affraid the rougher texture from removing the raft may result in even more work neccesary compared to printing it standing.

comments.text: I have done both one small one with not track texture and one with.  they are both super cool.  only proplem i had was gettinmg the train on to the track. i snapped off one of the small pieces that hold the train on.  so a little gorilla glue andi little snip off a side of track took care of the problem.  Both had what i thought were really good detail.

Heavily modified to be printable, this NASCAR styled race car prints with minimal supports, tires and rims print separately and snap together, rims are then glued to the main car chassis. Ripe for modifications, feel free to expand and modify to your hearts content.  
NOTE: The air spoilers are very thin and may not print properly depending on your slicing application, removing or thickening the spoilers may be required.
Printed with Standard settings with latest Makerbot software, .2mm layers with raft and supports, 10% fill. Print time was just under 4 hours on a Z18.
